The Europeans were never "freeloaders."

At first, they were smashed by World War 2. They didn't because they couldn't. We defended them from the Soviets because we and the Soviets were the only ones with the power to take or save Europe.

As Europe recovered, it did more. By the end of the Cold War, the German Army was the major defense, not the American Army. The Germans had 12 Panzer Divisions on the border, at a time when the entire US Army worldwide was 16 division, including infantry and 2 paratrooper divisions.

After the Cold War, we all talked about a "peace dividend." Everyone took one, except the US. Even the former Soviets took one -- their 300+ division army dropped to under a dozen, and the Americans came into Russia to help them dispose of their arms and ammo, and especially their nuclear weapons.

So now the Europeans enjoy the peace dividend and we don't. That was our choice, not to be blamed on them. 

In fact, the remaining US Army is NOT in Europe. All those American divisions are gone, all of them. All that is left is one parachute brigade on Italy. Our Armored Corps from Europe went to Iraq, and then went back to the US.

The vast US defense spending benefits Europe only indirectly. It isn't there. The US controls the world to the extent it does for the benefit of the US, not as some favor to Europe.

What Trump demands is for Europe to provide battalions of auxiliary troops to deploy with American armies in far distant places. Europe so far refused.

Most european countries offer generous benefits to its citizens, knowing the USA will cover their military defense. Taxpayers here pay indirectly for those benefits since we allow the Europeans to stint on their own defense spending. 

This is nothing new. Most european countries were unprepared for both WWI and WWII.

commentBody: That comes with signing up to be the world's hegemon. If you want to be the number one super power, put your dollars where your mouth is.

The combined defence budget of NATO is just over a trillion US$. The US accounts for almost two-thirds of that, dedicating nearly 4% of it's GDP to the effort along with all its other global strategic priorities. Still that leaves the European members of NATO spending $366 billion a year on defence. Russia spends $64 billion a year. Yes, it's a bit of apples and oranges and I'd take a few grains of salt with any figures provided by the Kremlin, especially if they pertain to defence and security. Still, why are we spending so much? And why does almost everyone say we need to spend more? Because if I was in the Kremlin, I'd be the one feeling afraid.

This article is misleading -every NATO member is meeting their commitment financially to NATO. The 2% target is for overall military spending-NOT necessarily on NATO.  It's an important distinction because President Trump keeps lying about this. The other countries should meet that commitment within a reasonable period of time in my opinion but it's that target is not NATO spending.

A good piece Mr Stephens.  Sure NATO has many problems, military preparedness being one of them. It's still the best option among all the alternatives. It really dismays me that more Republicans and voices on the right are not talking up the value of the NATO alliance.  For starters, they should make it absolutely clear to Trump, that the US pulling out of NATO is absolutely not an option.  If necessary, Congress should write legislation that gives Congress the ability to cancel such a move should Trump try to take it.

Re: "Trump thinks that most alliance members, starting with France and Canada, are a bunch of ungrateful and unhelpful freeloaders. Fair to say, also, that most of those members see Trump as an erratic, pompous, dangerous simpleton.

There’s no reason they both can’t be right."

Tell that to the families of Canadian solders that have died from Korea to Iraq and Afghanistan. Tell it to the American diplomats who were sheltered in Tehran by the Canadian ambassador at great personal risk to himself and to the Canadian foreign service officers when our embassy staff was taken hostage in 1979.

As a Canadian, I'd ask Americans to look at this another way.  The only time that NATO's Article 5 provision has been invoked was on behalf of the United States after the 9/11 attacks.  As a consequence Canada, along with other NATO allies have spilled a significant amount of blood and treasure in Afghanistan on behalf of the United States.

There was no conceivable benefit to Canada in participating in this war.  We weren't attacked.  We could have easily chosen to remained on the sidelines.  But we didn't.  We came, and we bled.

And what was the American reaction?  Well, it would seem that current American President (along with a lot of other Americans) have come to the conclusion that 170 dead and  as many crippled Canadians constitutes "freeloading".   (As an aside, I'd point out that this makes our casualties in Afghanistan roughly equivalent to America's, on a per capita basis)  In the new MAGA era, blood (apparently) doesn't count.  Only dollars.

Which leaves me wondering -- why did we bother?  It's clearly not appreciated -- heck it's not even acknowledged.  Not one American in 100 knows that we were even there. 
 And -- come to think of it -- when was the last time any member of the American army, navy or air force put themselves in harm's way (much less taken a bullet) on Canada's behalf?

Something to think about, come next time.
Can we meet the 2% target too?

It is a simplistic and inherently vile attack that Stephens issues - that many NATO states are freeloaders.

This literally means he (like Trump) holds these other NATO members to be taking advantage of the generosity of the US, and giving nothing in return.

Tell that to the fallen soldiers who gave everything they had when called on in Iraq or Afghanistan. Tell that to the injured, the maimed.

Given nothing? What a shameful construct to use. Totally and utterly despicable. Beneath contempt.
Not to mention the fact that the British term is Nato or, for that matter, Nasa.  They can't even invest in Capital Letters....
The one trump reminds me of most is Muammar Ghaddfi of Libya.  Comes in, does his nonsensical spouting then leaves with nothing. And totally ineffectual at anything.

Don't be so worried about Europe's unpreparedness for war. For centuries European nations have proven their ability to fight when necessary. To disastrous effect. Why do we want to encourage more of this? NATO is about peace and deterrence, not saber-rattling.

I grew up in Berlin surrounded by the Wall and the hope that NATO was there and not too far away if the inevitable happened.
The "inevitable" being Russian troops marching into the West-Sektor just like they always threatened to do. 
Most Americans know nothing of living with this fear because they've never had to, especially because there's an ocean that separates them from the initial threat. -- but it's very different living in Europe on a continent with borders that can easily be crossed.
That's why we depended on the USA and looked to it as one might look to a beloved guardian.
And even though some things may have changed, the need for America to champion Democracy and the free world is just as important as ever because the threat to extinguish it still exists.
Hopefully this country and its European counterparts in NATO can overcome their differences in order to keep this trans-Atlantic organization alive.
It's more than dollars and cents that's at stake.
And in the end, we're still all in this together.

To begin with there is an obscene amount of money spent on military hardware all over.  We spend huge amounts, a good percentage of which is wasted following the desires of the armament industry.  I think that countries have now learned that taking over other people's land is not a profitable  enterprise. (The Israel example is an outlier. )
European wars have been  a result of this obsession and a desire for "glory".  In the last century fear of  German imperial ambitions was dominant in France and Russia and provoked the disaster of WWII.  The same fear that fed US-Russia postwar paranoia has led to  an unbearable atomic confrontation.  Eastern Europe lives in fear of Russia and any move we take to allay their concern pushes Russia to dangerous actions.  So, I don't see how spending more money  on weapons gets us anywhere.

Europe buys a pile of American weapons systems, the economies of scale lower U.S. costs and better positions those American systems to be sold internationally.   So even with their anemic military budgets they still help U.S. strategic posture by buying the weapons.  And these weapons--so long as they are truly "tight allies"--are also available to be lent back to the U.S. under the theoretical case where a surge in demand (during a conflict) made them necessary to forces elsewhere. 

So it's not all bad.  And even Japan, spending only 1% of its GDP on the military--well, it's a big GDP.  Japan has one of the world's larger armed forces as a result.  Ditto Germany.
Agree with Paul McGlasson - a thoughtful, fair and balanced analysis.

This is why the Trumpists are wrong on so many foreign policy fronts. By funding NATO we buy security. We're not protecting Europe. We're protecting ourselves. Money we have in abundance. Security, not so much. The whole post-WW2 international structure was created for our advantage, by wiser men and women than now hold the reins of power.

I also can't speak for all Canadians but Canada's position has always been that we contribute in a number of non-military ways to the alliance.  Whether or not that position holds water we prefer not to discuss too much.   

What IS true is that Canada is safe behind  a frigid ocean a vast wilderness to the north,  Ocean to the east and west and a friendly superpower to the south.  

Perhaps most importantly, Canada isn't running a globe-spanning empire.

When the US spends on defense, almost all the money goes from the US federal government to US arms manufacturers.  Our bloated defense budget is, essentially, corporate welfare for the benefit of US corporations.  And there are benefits:  military spending helps maintain the US's manufacturing base and heavy industry.  

And with its bloated war machine, the US gets to bully other nations to have its way and protect its economic interests on foreign soil.  All very good for Uncle Sam.  

So, the money the US government "spends" on defense really redounds to economic vigor of the US itself.  When Canada or European countries spend on military hardware, a sizable chunk of that money goes toward buying US products.  Big difference there, and really, the US needs to give up its martyr complex.

The US did all it could to turn Germany into a pacifist country after World War 2, so there's little point in whining about it "underspending" on its military today.

The United States makes up only 4% of the world's population but consumes over 20% of its resources.  It has a lot of skin in this game and owes the world big time.  Without its efforts to police and secure stability around the world its citizens will lose big time in every way; economically, terrorist attacks, etc.   At least, think of your own self interests!

Alliances are always difficult but they are necessary. Trump has a view of international relations that is just without any foundation upon anything relevant. He just cannot appreciate why we have bases and troops in other countries. 

Anyone who remembers the build up to the Gulf War which drove Iraq from Kuwait can appreciate how much time it takes to assemble forces and to engage an enemy. In contemporary times, not having advanced bases and forces able to fight, the time needed to assemble and engage the enemy is many weeks at a time when wars can be decided in days. So we are forced to deploy forces across the globe. 

As much as our allies may seem like slackers, they have all committed themselves and allow our forces to reside inside of their countries. This by itself is of great benefit to us. While shifting the burden from our people to their people, it's not an advantage for us when one appreciates that that shifts control over our defense to others. It means that if they cannot perform up to our expectations, we can just pound sand.
